Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: The cohomology and birational geometry of moduli spaces
Award.AbstractNarration:
Homogeneous varieties, in particular, ordinary and isotropic Grassmannians, are central objects of study in algebraic geometry, representation theory, and combinatorics. The investigator proposes to develop positive algorithms for computing the structure constants of the cohomology of isotropic Grassmannians and isotropic flag varieties. In recent years, similar positive algorithms have led to the solutions of many important problems for Type A Grassmannians, including the saturation conjecture and the reality of Schubert calculus. The investigator will also study the effective cones of the moduli space of curves and stable maps. The moduli spaces of curves are among the most studied objects in mathematics. Their cones of effective divisors are important invariants, intimately tied to problems such as the Schottky problem, the Kodaira dimension of the moduli space of curves, and the existence of modular forms. Recently, understanding the effective cone of moduli spaces has received new impetus following the seminal work of Hacon, McKernan, and their collaborators on the Minimal Model Program (MMP). The investigator proposes to run MMP on moduli spaces such as the Kontsevich moduli spaces of genus zero stable maps or Hilbert scheme of points on the projective plane.

Systems of polynomial equations occur in many facets of life ranging from evolutionary biology to physics and from cryptography to computer science. Algebraic geometry studies geometric properties of solutions of polynomial systems. The solutions that have many symmetries are especially interesting and important. For example, a sphere is a perfectly symmetric space in the sense that any point can be rotated to any other point. The investigator studies the number of solutions to polynomial systems involving such perfectly symmetric spaces called homogeneous varieties. The investigator also calculates more subtle geometric invariants of systems of polynomial equations such as how the behavior of the space of solutions changes under perturbations of the system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: Algebraic geometry studies geometric properties of solutions of polynomial systems called varieties. The space of n-tuples of points on a variety is itself a variety called the Hilbert scheme of points. The geometry of this space plays an important role in many branches of mathematics and physics.  

In joint work with Arcara, Bertram and Huizenga, the PI applied Bridgeland stability conditions, a transformative new tool inspired by string theory, to study the geometry of Hilbert schemes of points on surfaces and certain generalizations called moduli spaces of sheaves. The PI resolved several long standing questions about the geometry of these spaces. For example, in joint work with Huizenga and Woolf, he computed the effective cones of moduli spaces of sheaves on the plane and solved the higher rank interpolation problem. The interpolation problem asks for polynomials of small degree satisfying a given data set. 

The PI studied the geometry of the Deligne-Mumford moduli space of stable curves. This space parameterizes complex structures on a curve and is a central object of study in mathematics. In joint work with Chen, the PI constructed infinitely many extremal rays for the effective cone of the Deligne-Mumford moduli spaces of pointed genus-one curves. This was surprising because it showed that these cones could be very complicated and raised doubts about several long standing conjectures.

The PI made several breakthroughs in related areas. In joint work with Chen, he studied higher codimension cycles on moduli spaces of curves. In joint work with Lesieutre and Ottem, the PI computed cones of higher codimension cycles on blowups of projective spaces at points. The study of cones of higher codimension cycles is a new area of research. The PI obtained several unexpected results that might point to further developments in the theory. 

Broader Impact: The PI organized more than 10 summer schools and workshops aimed at graduate students and postdocs. Most notably, he co-organized the Graduate Student Bootcamp preceding the Utah Algebraic Geometry Summer Institute, the preeminent conference in algebraic geometry that takes place once every decade. Several of these workshops were very influential in introducing young US researchers to cutting edge developments such as Bridgeland stability conditions and higher codimension cycles.

The PI is dedicated to training the next generation of STEM researchers. He has supervised 9 PhD students and 7 postdocs. He has also mentored numerous undergraduate students, supervised 4 undergraduate research projects and 3 high school research projects.
